utterances.utterance: We told you about all the sanctions that are in place right now to put the screws on Vladimir Putin. A lot of them are coming from businesses and institutions that aren't hearing government orders. They're doing it themselves. And they're unleashing untold damage to Vladimir Putin, if he'd ever admit it -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, racing to put the screws on Vladimir Putin and Russia quite literally right now, because the Russian Grand Prix is off. It's a major, major event, a Formula One auto race, not going to be happening right now. Nate Foy joins us, with us. Nate is just starting with FOX. So I introduced him on FOX Business. It's an honor to have him. And welcome again here on FOX News, Nate. What's going on here?

utterances.speaker: NATE FOY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Neil, it's an honor to be here. A big reversal today. Russian and Belarusian athletes will not be allowed to compete in the Paralympics, which start tomorrow in Beijing. Listen here.

utterances.speaker: ANDREW PARSONS, PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONAL PARALYMPIC COMMITTEE
utterances.utterance: We are also firm believers that sport and politics should not mix. However, it is clear that maybe now, due to the current situation, that is no longer possible.

utterances.speaker: FOY
utterances.utterance: The IPC reversing the decision from yesterday, initially saying athletes could compete, but under a neutral flag. And you mentioned it, Neil, also today, Formula One releasing this statement, saying it's terminated its contract with the Russian Grand Prix promoter, meaning Russia will not have a race in the future. Amid threats of financial sanctions, Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich is selling the Premier League's Chelsea football club. Proceeds of that sale will benefit victims of the war in Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: We're getting a new perspective on the war today. Ukrainian boxing champion Wladimir Klitschko, who's fighting alongside his brother Vitali, who you see here, the mayor of Kyiv, has this to say about Western policies against Russia
WLADIMIR KLITSCHKO, FORMER UKRAINIAN BOXER
utterances.utterance: We need to stop this madness, because all the money that Russia is getting is getting used for buying lethal weapons that are killing Ukrainians.

utterances.speaker: FOY
utterances.utterance: The Klitschko brothers are fighting alongside fellow champion boxers Vasiliy Lomachenko and Oleksandr Usyk -- Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, Nate, thank you very much. Welcoming you again, my friend. Many, many more times, hope to be together with you, Nick Foy on all of those developments. Right now, let's go to Ambassador Alexander Vershbow, the former deputy secretary-general of NATO and our U.S. ambassador to Russia. Ambassador, good to have you.

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDER VERSHBOW, FORMER NATO DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL
utterances.utterance: Nice to be here, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: These various measures, Ambassador, from sanctions all the way down to a Russian Grand Prix event that is shelved, other Olympic events and athletic events and entertainment events and international business conferences, Vladimir Putin and Russia in general persona, country non grata. And I'm wondering how much of an impact do you think that has. I mean, it takes a while to implement, but certainly, looking at Vladimir Putin, it's not giving him any pause. So where do you see these measures going?

utterances.speaker: VERSHBOW
utterances.utterance: Well, I think he's obviously going to feel much more direct pain from the sanctions, which are quite extraordinary in terms of how sweeping they are, much stronger than the sanctions that we imposed back in 2014 after the first invasion of Ukraine. But these symbolic moves of just excluding the Russians from sport and cultural events, I think, is one way to get through the fog of Russian propaganda, and make clear to the Russian people that their leader has isolated them from the entire international community. He's taken them down the road to becoming a pariah, a rogue state in the eyes of the world. And, hopefully, as more information trickles into Russian viewers, besides the state propaganda, they will begin to put some pressure from below. And, meanwhile, the oligarchs and the KGB guys may also begin to press their boss to say, look, you have -- you're in over your head. It's time to de- escalate.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: As our former ambassador to Russia, I'm just wondering, who might be supporting this? Obviously, some of Vladimir Putin's oligarch friends aren't too happy about it. Is he aligning himself more with the military, then, that would be supporting this, or are military figures anxious as well?

utterances.speaker: VERSHBOW
utterances.utterance: Well, as always, we don't have a clear picture of domestic factors behind the scenes. But there were some interesting dissents from retired military in the run- up to the war. A leading hard-liner, Leonid Ivashov, published an open letter on behalf of a veterans organization, accusing Putin of starting an unnecessary war, taking Russia down the path of international pariah status, and urging his president to resign. That was quite remarkable. And people thought that that may have reflected at least some disagreement with what Putin was doing among the active-duty military officers. So, now, whether Putin hears any direct criticism from these people directly, that's doubtful. He's walled himself off from most of his people who might have a dissenting view. He's just got a bunch of yes-men, former KGB people, in his inner circle. And they tell him what he wants to hear, and blame everything on the United States. So I think it's going to be the economic sanctions that begin to squeeze the bank accounts of the oligarchs and some of these KGB cronies around Putin. And only until that happens will any real pressure be felt by Putin himself, any sense that he's made a mistake. We saw in his own exchange with Macron today and in his public remarks that he's full speed ahead with his maximum demands, no sign of looking for an off-ramp.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's very clear. He ended the phone call: Russia will achieve its goals. I'm just wondering, Ambassador, then what those goals are. If he installs a puppet government or returns to the guy who was running the country, who was all but chased out of the country and brought us President Zelensky, I'm wondering where you see a Ukraine, if Russia were to succeed, as a country. Now, Putin had said earlier today that, "I'm proud to be part of a multinational people of Russia," saying that Ukrainians and Russians are -- quote -- "one people. They deserve to be one people." So how would he play that out if he got what he wanted?

utterances.speaker: VERSHBOW
utterances.utterance: Well, that's going to be a challenge for him. I mean, it's one thing to take control of some of the cities. And they do ultimately have superior capabilities, even if they botched a lot of the initial phase of this operation. But trying to actually secure their hold on the cities and on the country as a whole is going to be difficult, because the Ukrainians are not going to accept any puppet leader that installs, surely not former President Yanukovych. But even if they find some less toxic figure, he will be immediately public enemy number one for all Ukrainians. So, there's going to be a resistance, there's going to be an insurgency, which could extend over many years, similar to what the Russians faced in Afghanistan 40 years ago. So, in the short term, he may gain control, at least in a formal sense, over Ukraine, but he's not going to gain control over the Ukrainian people. And this insurgency could begin to weaken the Russian grip. And, at the same time, as more Russian boys come home in body bags, it could fuel the domestic opposition to this whole adventure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Real quickly, you know the Russian people. I raised this with other guys, who are saying, the longer this does drag on, the more the Russian people will get annoyed. Whatever little they know, they certainly know the economic hit, and they're going to tire of it, and it could happen in weeks, no matter what's going on in Ukraine. Do you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: VERSHBOW
utterances.utterance: I do. And I think the sanctions package has had almost immediate effect in some respects, with the ruble crashing, Russia fully blocked from access to the international financial system. All the state banks are cut off. And, of course, we're seeing, even without sanctions, the American and European companies are, well, making a quick exodus from the Russian market. I think the big challenge for us and for the Ukrainians too, to some extent, is to get more information to the general public in Russia. Those who watch state TV are not yet even aware of the scope of the Russian operation or the fact that they're actively bombing one of everybody's favorite cities, Kyiv. As -- if we can use social media and other methods to get real information into the Russian audience, that could accelerate the process of undermining Putin's political base.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Got it. Yes, get the word out, the clear word, the honest word, the truthful word. You're right. Ambassador, very good seeing you. Thank you very much for taking the time.

utterances.speaker: VERSHBOW
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The pinch, though, is still on. And this is the pinch for the globe, higher energy prices going still, still higher. Can you say $4 gas, maybe $5 gas? After this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Oil prices keep rocketing. That means gas prices can't be too far behind. They have already been soaring. Indications are now, with the latest oil news, they could soar a lot more, $4, $5 gas. Your pick. Jeff Flock in Philadelphia with more on side of the story. Hi, Jeff

utterances.speaker: JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: To quote the old Brooks & Dunn song, Neil, cost of living is high and going up. Yes, up to $5 today in San Francisco, on average, $4 here in the Philadelphia suburbs, as you perhaps see behind me. And if you look at the national average, $3.73 now, up 7 cents today alone after up 4 cents yesterday, and the cost of diesel similar, 8 cents today. Yes, diesel of course, a lot of potential for inflation there with all the trucks that run diesel. And individual stations, I took a picture at one station we were at earlier today. Started out when we got there at $3.89 at the Shell station on Broad Street, $4.05 before long, a 16 cent increase in one day, diesel pretty much the same. I report to you tonight from the Lukoil station here in Abington Township. That's Willow Grove, Pennsylvania. Lukoil, you might know, is a Russian company, one of the biggest oil companies in Russia. They have got about 5,000 gas stations worldwide, about 200-plus here in the U.S. And the city council in the city of Newark, New Jersey, has voted to suspend the Lukoil stations there, out of solidarity with Ukraine. Problem is that the stations are franchise-owned. That is to say, they're operated and owned by Americans and employing Americans. And one of those franchise holders spoke out today, said he certainly supports Ukraine, but he does not support being put out of business. Listen.

utterances.speaker: ROGER VERMA, LUKOIL GAS STATION OWNER
utterances.utterance: Let me be clear when I say that I stand with Ukraine, and I'm fully in support of Russian sanctions. However, I am baffled and confused how shutting down an American-based small business owner is sending a message to support. I'm just totally baffled.

utterances.speaker: FLOCK
utterances.utterance: One other note on Lukoil, they have actually become, the Russian company, now one of the first in the U.S. and Russia to speak out against the invasion of Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: I quote them now. And they say
utterances.utterance: "We stand for the immediate cessation of armed conflict in Ukraine and support diplomatic efforts." Good luck, sir.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, right, maybe because of what's happening behind you, with those signs. Those look like incredible prices. Jeff Flock, thank you very, very much, my friend.

utterances.speaker: FLOCK
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: A little eye-popping, isn't it? You're going to see more of that. Meanwhile, Mike Tobin in Lviv, Ukraine, where they have far, far bigger worries on their hands -- Michael.

utterances.speaker: MIKE TOBIN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: They certainly do, with the fighting in the northeast and the south. The refugee traffic is coming west. The drive to -- from Kyiv here to Lviv normally takes six hours. It's taking 18 hours right now. And it is chock full of checkpoints and peril. That's why I have a lot of people taking the train from Kyiv to this location. That train gets absolutely packed. Your ticket doesn't mean anything at all. People just get on board and start heading west. When they get here to Kyiv, some people -- or good here to Lviv, I should say -- some people are staying. Some people continue west to the border. The UNHCR now says that 1,045,000 refugees have gone west across the border. Most of them, 52 percent, are going into Poland. Others are heading into Moldova, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania looking for refuge. A few people have gone north into Belarus. By few, I mean a few thousand. And about 43,000 have headed east, seeking to get away from the fighting by going into Russia -- Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, Mike, every day, you hear more and more attacks, certainly those seemingly deliberately targeting civilians.

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The people in that city behind you obviously know that and they have gotten word of that. This pace could pick up with each and every day. I mean, how real is that threat to them? Or do they still think there's a way this can be stopped?

utterances.speaker: TOBIN
utterances.utterance: No, they have accepted the idea that they're a nation at war. And everyone pitches in. We have seen people pitching in to get the aid that comes into the country. You have got to get into the conflict zone. So there's a big distribution center, where they're all working. Everyone's volunteering. And then people get in their cars and drive at great peril to make sure the aid gets to places like Kherson, like Kharkiv, where the people need it so badly. You got people out here in welding shops stop doing their business. They're taking old railroad ties and I-beams and making what are called hedgehog barriers that -- old World War I type of design that are intended to stop tanks. Everyone is pitching in and doing what they can. They have very much accepted that they're a nation at war.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, Mike, be safe. Mike Tobin in Libya, Ukraine. Any signs that Vladimir Putin would be slowing down here or getting concerned about all the sanctions and everything else, he has indicated, as if it's any surprise, it's full throttle. He wants Ukraine, and he's determined to get it. Here's "The Five." Content and Programming Copyright 2022 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2022 VIQ Media Transcription, Inc.
